sections.title: Check Your Essay
sections.description: Use this checklist to review your work

items.label: Introduction clearly paraphrases the question (not copied)
tips: Use synonyms: invest → allocate funds, public transport → mass transit, roads → highway infrastructure

items.label: Body paragraph 1 has clear topic sentence about public transport
tips: Topic sentence = first sentence stating main argument

items.label: Body paragraph 2 discusses road infrastructure
tips: Use transition: However, On the other hand, Conversely

items.label: Conclusion summarizes both views + states opinion clearly
tips: Your opinion must be clear - which deserves more investment?

items.label: Both views are discussed with equal detail
tips: Count sentences - each view should have similar length

items.label: Personal opinion is clearly stated
tips: Use: In my view, I believe that, From my perspective

items.label: Specific examples are provided for each view
tips: Real examples like specific cities or countries are strongest

items.label: All parts of the question are fully addressed
No repeated words - synonyms used throughout
tips: public transport → mass transit, public transit systems

items.label: Topic vocabulary from Section 2 is used correctly
Complex sentences are used (not all simple sentences)
tips: Use: who, which, that, although, while, because

items.label: Verb tenses are consistent and correct

sections.title: Band 8 Model Answer
sections.description: Compare your essay with this high-band example

essay.fullEssay:
The allocation of government funding between public transit systems and road infrastructure remains a contentious issue among policymakers and citizens. While both types of investment serve important functions, I believe public transport deserves greater priority due to its environmental and social benefits.

On the one hand, prioritizing public transport investment addresses multiple pressing urban challenges simultaneously. Mass transit systems reduce traffic congestion and environmental pollution by moving large populations efficiently with significantly lower carbon emissions per capita than private vehicles. For instance, Tokyo's extensive metro network transports millions of commuters daily while maintaining relatively clean air quality compared to car-dependent cities. Furthermore, affordable public transportation ensures social equity by providing mobility options for low-income residents who cannot afford private vehicles, enabling them to access employment, education, and healthcare. This makes public transit investment not merely an infrastructure decision but a crucial social policy.

On the other hand, road infrastructure undeniably plays a vital role in economic development and comprehensive connectivity. Well-maintained highway networks facilitate freight transportation that sustains supply chains and commercial activities essential to modern economies. Additionally, rural communities heavily depend on road access for reaching markets, services, and emergency facilities that public transport networks cannot feasibly serve. Roads also provide the flexibility and point-to-point connectivity that many individuals and businesses require for their daily operations. These practical considerations make road maintenance and expansion impossible to ignore entirely.

In conclusion, while road infrastructure serves important economic and accessibility functions, public transport offers superior environmental sustainability and social benefits, particularly in densely populated urban areas. Governments should therefore allocate greater resources to public transit systems while maintaining essential road networks, striking a balance that prioritizes long-term sustainability over individual convenience.

strengths: Clear position with well-reasoned opinion favoring public transport
Both views discussed equally with specific examples
Strong topic sentences in each paragraph
Wide range of vocabulary (contentious, capita, undeniably)
Complex sentence structures with varied grammar
